document.masterDocTitle: Studies of Madagascan Ptiliidae (Coleoptera) 4: The genus Bambara including eight new species and the first account of blindness and aptery in the genus

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Studies of Madagascan Ptiliidae (Coleoptera) 4: The genus Bambara including eight new species and the first account of blindness and aptery in the genus

subSubSection.paragraph:
Habitus Fig. 8 . Length +/- 750 µ. Colour brownish yellow, the pronotum darker than the elytra. Antenna length +/- 270 µ,
Fig. 15
. Pronotum length 217 µ min, 232 µ max, 223 µ mean; width 385 µ min, 403 µ max, 393 µ mean; ratio width/length 1.76 . Detached elytron length 455 µ min, 480 µ max, 468 µ mean; width 248 µ min, 273 µ max, 263 µ mean, ratio length/width 1.78 ; Fig. 19 . Ratio mean elytra length/mean pronotum length 2.10 .

Male : aedeagus without any features to reliably distinguish it from other
Bambara
Figs 48 a–b.; tail section of a spermatazoon showing coils Fig. 51 . Abdominal ventrite 7 Fig. 52 .
Etymology . Refers to the Merina Kingdom, established in Madagascar in 1787 , when the burning of forests was forbidden and irrigation canals built.

Diagnosis . The U-shape of the spermatheca clearly places this species in the group which comprises
B. invisibilis , B. testacea , B. frosti
and
B. sublutea
. From the last three
merina
may be separated by the proximity of the gland insertion point to the end of the lower arm of the lumen coupled with the greater length of the upper arm (the same as or slightly longer than the lower arm). These will also separate it from from
invisibilis
in which the gland insertion and pump are aligned above each other. Confirmation of the separation from
invisibilis
is also provided by the number of coils in the tail section of the spermatazoa which are much fewer than those illustrated by L.& H. Dybas for that species (
Dybas & Dybas, 1981
).
